Jewel food stores in surrounding suburbs will have to replace several refrigeration units to meet Environmental Protection Agency guidelines PERIOD

Jewel Foods Inc PERIOD will convert old refrigeration units at  stores into nonCFC chlorofluorocarbon emitting units by  according to a recent federal court agreement PERIOD

Jewel also agreed to pay a civil penalty of  for alleged CFC leaks and promised to use EPAapproved refrigerants in future stores PERIOD Any store with more than three significant leaks in a year will also be changed according to the U.S PERIOD Department of Justice Web site PERIOD

Affected stores are located in Cook DuPage Kane Lake McHenry and Will counties PERIOD The agreement will not affect the local JewelOsco at  Sycamore Road PERIOD

The problem with CFCs is that they have effects that long outlast their original date of manufacture biological science professor Peter Meserve said PERIOD The ozone hole over the Antarctic continues to persist and grow and no one really knows when that will stop. a treaty in September  establishing that CFCs would be globally phased out by the year  was signed by  countries and the European Economic Community PERIOD

The actual complaint was filed on Feb PERIOD  along with the consent decree said George Czerniak chief of the air enforcement branch of the EPA PERIOD The violation was something that we had determined in  PERIOD We have been talking about a resolution with them since that time. ePA investigators discovered the problem when they looked at records from Jewel facilities and discovered information about the repair of leaks in the refrigerants they put into the system Czerniak said PERIOD

There was no effect on the food stored in the units PERIOD More information on the hole in the ozone layer and the treaty can be found at www.theozonehole.commontreal.htm PERIOD
